abstract.p: Drive systems as used in machinery and technical applications often suffer from insufficient system damping. In order to improve the damping characteristic, the method of semi-active control is proposed. Specific requirements associated with drive systems are pointed out and addressed in the course of this paper. Based on the classical sky-hook damping a novel semi-active control strategy, well suited for use in drive systems, is presented. The fundamental background is explained on a two-degree-of-freedom (2-DOF) drive model and stability is proven by means of the direct method of Lyapunov. Finally the control strategy is verified on an experimental test bench and proof for the effectiveness and applicability of this method is given.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
The concept of semi-active control is a well-known method and has been used in many mechanical and civil engineering applications. Semi-active control was first proposed by Karnopp et al. (1974) as a method of emulating the sky-hook concept presented 1 year earlier (Crosby and Karnopp, 1973). Figure 1 schematically shows the theoretical concept of sky-hook damping where a damper is connected to an inertial reference, and a typical practical implementation of the idea (Ledezma-Ramirez et al., 2010). Figure 1.
(a) Theoretical sky-hook concept. (b) Practical implementation of semi-active damping.

The term semi-active, in this case, refers to the use of an adaptable damping device, exclusively capable of dissipating energy. In contrast to a passive damper, the force generated by a semi-active damper is varied on-line according to feedback signals and control commands. Over the decades various control algorithms have been developed and analysed. Most of these algorithms can be assigned to either sky-hook or balance control. While sky-hook damping intends to produce the effect of the theoretical sky-hook concept, the idea behind balance control is to cancel the spring force by an adequate damping force with opposite sign. Depending on the determination of the damping coefficient, both techniques once more can be categorized into continuous and on/off type control. Continuous control, as the name implies, uses a continuously variable coefficient in order to produce the desired damping characteristic. In its pure form this will lead to infinitely large values. In terms of the on/off type control, the damping coefficient is switched between a fixed maximum and minimum value. A good overview on the different strategies can be found in Liu (2002) and Liu and Brennan (2005). Next to these methods, numerous, more sophisticated control strategies such as sliding mode controllers (Chen, 2009), LQR controllers (Dyke et al., 1998) or fuzzy logic controllers (Song et al., 2009) are documented in the literature.

The aim of all of these methods is to diminish energy, suppress or isolate oscillations and improve the dynamical characteristic of a system in an optimal way. General conditions in this context are the complexity of the control law, the acquisition effort for state variables necessary and the power required for the semi-active damping device. In spite of their simplicity, on/off type control strategies have shown to achieve very good effects, almost comparable to those of continuous control laws (Liu and Brennan, 2005). Their good performance and low complexity ensure that these control laws possess a particular practical importance.

The field of application for semi-active control is manifold and reaches from seismic protection in civil engineering, over vehicle suspensions in automotive industries to structural damping in machines and aerospace applications (Majeed, 1990; Dyke et al., 1998; Stammers and Sireteanu, 1998). A large amount of research has been performed and the effectiveness and performance of control strategies and damping devices have continuously been improved.

This paper now adopts the idea of semi-active damping control to drive systems, as used in machinery and technical applications. The fundamental concept aims at the selective manipulation of the system damping in order to suppress unwanted oscillations and thereby improve the overall dynamical behaviour. With the focus on drive systems, this paper presents yet another field of application for semi-active control that so far has not received much attention. To apply this technique to drive systems, certain requirements have to be met. Overall, a novel on/off type, semi-active control strategy has been developed and implemented. The principle of this method is presented and compared with that of a classical on/off type sky-hook concept. The applicability of the method to drive systems is verified and experimental measurements obtained on a test bench are presented.

sec.title: 2. Semi-active control strategy for drive systems
sec.p: A drive system can be described as an essential part of a technical application, transmitting the power of an actuator onto a certain object in order to create a defined motion. Many technical applications use transmission elements such as converters and gear mechanisms to manipulate the motion of the drive unit, for example that of an electric motor, as to best fit the application. The mechanical transmission elements (these can be ball screw or belt drives, gear boxes, shafts and couplings or rack and pinion drives amongst others) often determine the characteristic of the drive system, leading to distinctive and typically slightly damped eigenmodes.

Figure 2 shows a generally accepted model of a drive system, equally valid for rotational and/or linear drive configurations (Zirn and Weikert, 2006). Figure 2.
Two-degree-of-freedom model of a drive system.

The simplified drive model consists of two lumped masses m1 and m2 representing the motor and load of the drive system. The input embodies the actual drive, e.g. an electric motor coupled to a ball screw, and the output the object to be moved. Each mass can move independently with respect to the inertial system. The transmission between input and output is represented by a spring with constant stiffness k and a viscous damper with the damping coefficient csys. With regard to the presence of friction, two inertial dampers c1 and c2 have been added to the model. While c1 once again is considered as an ideal viscous damper, c2 represents a variable damping element used for the semi-active control strategy. The following considerations are based on the simplified drive model depicted in Figure 2.

sec.title: 2.1. Specific requirements of drive systems
sec.p: Drive systems for the field of industrial applications such as machine tools and manufacturing units usually involve high demands on accuracy and dynamics. These systems generally experience certain excitations during operation, which either arise from the input itself or from external forces acting on the output. Any jerk imposed onto the system can cause unwanted oscillations that interfere with the actual motion profile and influence the accuracy of the system. In this context, disturbance rejection is an important issue concerning the applicability of a drive system. Furthermore properties such as long-term stability, efficiency, robustness towards changing operating conditions and a preferably linear transmission behaviour are essential for the functionality of a drive system.

Generally speaking, high jerk values and the lack of system damping, as present in many technical applications, can lead to unwanted oscillations and overshoot in the position. This lowers the quality of the motion characteristics and increases the time for positioning. In applications where overshoot is not acceptable, the mechanical transmission elements often directly limit the achievable dynamics of the drive system, demanding relatively low jerk values for the input (Pritschow, 1998). An appropriate damping characteristic is therefore preferable in almost every drive system, allowing for a better command tracking and disturbance rejection and therefore for an improved overall performance.

When trying to improve the damping characteristics of the drive system depicted in Figure 2, either the inertial or the system damping have to be increased. Considering practical aspects of drive systems, in most cases, it is convenient to control the force of the inertial damper mounted to the drive’s output represented by the mass m2. By this means, the energy dissipated by the damper will be conducted onto the inertial system and not the input of the drive, allowing for both resonance control and high-frequency isolation. In principle this set-up offers the possibility to realize an ideal sky-hook damper by solely increasing the value of c2. A constantly high value for c2, however, would lead to extremely large driving forces and an extensive energy loss at high velocities. Such a mode of operation is not concordant with the requirements for drive systems stated above. In fact, it would be more desirable to regulate the damping force according to the actual operating condition: large damping forces during excitations and transient responses and considerably low damping forces at steady-state conditions. In order to achieve such a selective manipulation, a semi-active damping concept for the generally accepted drive model in Figure 2 is proposed.

The method of semi-active damping is generally well suited for the selective suppression of oscillations, such as those occurring in drive systems. The effectiveness and robustness of the control method, along with the possibility of using a passive actuator are some of the main advantages. At the same time however, semi-active damping strategies typically suffer from discontinuities of the control law, causing an abrupt change of the damping force at certain conditions. Therefore, significant jerk may be experienced by the respective mass during the process of switching, leading to unwanted oscillations of the system and excitation of higher order modes. To overcome this problem, several strategies have been presented in literature (Margolis and Goshtasbpour, 1984; Ahmadia et al., 2000) using more or less complex shaping functions for smoothing the state transitions of the control law. In contrast, this paper presents a novel control strategy with continuous state transitions, easy to implement and well suited to the application in drive systems. For reasons of its implementation, in the following it will be referred to as absolute value control.

sec.title: 2.2. Absolute value control
sec.p: One classical and at the same time highly effective control strategy is the so called on/off type sky-hook control expressed as follows: (1)Fd={c2(x·2-x·1),x·2(x·2-x·1)≥00,otherwise.

Using the state variable x·2 as a reference, the sky-hook control operates for the given application in a desirable way: oscillations between the input and output are suppressed while under steady-state conditions the controller is ineffective. The simplicity of the control law furthermore allows for an easy implementation and integration into existing systems. Only two state variables, namely the velocities of the two masses are needed in order to control the damping force. The condition function thereby incorporates the physical limitation of the passive damping device and accordingly switches between on- and off-state. Figure 3 shows the control surface for the sky-hook concept plotted over the state variables x·1 and x·2. Figure 3.
3D control surface for sky-hook control.

The discontinuity of the control law already mentioned is clearly noticeable. At certain state transitions an abrupt change of the damping force Fd can occur, leading to jerk and excitation of the vibrational modes of the system. Such a mode of operation is not compliant with the requirements stated above and therefore not preferable for the use in high-performance, high-accuracy drive systems.

The deficiency of the sky-hook control method, namely the discontinuity of the control law, in the same way applies to the strategy of balance control. Furthermore general conditions, such as the acquisition of additional state variables or static deviations due to impreciseness of the transmission elements, can lead to problems when imposing this method onto drive systems. On this account, the method of balance control does not appear preferable for this specific application and therefore will not be discussed further in the course of this paper.

Even though the methods of sky-hook and balance control might be suitable for less-demanding drive systems, at this point a different on/off type control strategy is proposed. Similar to the method of sky-hook control, the velocities of the two masses are compared and used to determine the force to be produced by the semi-active damper. In this case, however, not the relative velocity but the difference between the absolute values of the velocities is included into the control law. Accordingly the condition function has been modified in order to meet the requirements of a continuous control law: (2)Fd={c2sgn(x·2)(|x·2|-|x·1|),|x·2|-|x·1|≥00,otherwise.

Similar to the idea of sky-hook control, this control law ensures a selective variation of the damping force according to the operating condition of the drive system. In contrast to the foregoing concepts, however, the control law using the absolute velocity values shows continuous transitions over the entire state space. Figure 4 shows the 3D control surface for the proposed control law. Assuming an ideally controllable damping device with no delay time, switching will always occur during zero output force. Therefore, the system will experience no excitations due to switching of the damping action between the on- and off-value. The control law can be entirely implemented using the velocity values of the individual masses and basic mathematical operations. Figure 4.
3D control surface for absolute value control.

Figure 5 and Figure 6 show a qualitative comparison of sky-hook and absolute value control under different operating conditions. The simulation was performed on the two-degree-of-freedom (2-DOF) drive model with arbitrarily chosen system parameters. Using the example of a sinusoidal motion of the drive’s input m1, the difference between the two control laws can be seen quite clearly. In Figure 5 and Figure 6 the velocities x·1 and x·2 as well as the corresponding damping forces, determined by the respective control algorithm, are depicted. At operating conditions where both velocities hold the same algebraic sign, the control laws offer identical performance (Figure 5). However, when a zero crossing of the state variable x·2 occurs, the discontinuity of the sky-hook control law becomes evident. While for the operating mode in Figure 6 the absolute value control still guarantees smooth transition rates, the sky-hook control causes an abrupt switching of the damping force, leading to excitations and variations of the drive’s output velocity. At this point it should be mentioned, that in the case of a zero crossing of the velocities the absolute value control compromises some of the damping effect of the sky-hook control. This deficit, however, is rather irrelevant compared with the changing friction characteristics which typically occur at this operation point and therefore it shall be neglected in the following. Figure 5.
Comparison of sky-hook and absolute value control for a sinusoidal motion profile.
Figure 6.
Comparison of sky-hook and absolute value control for a sinusoidal motion profile with zero crossing of x·2.

The previous analysis has shown that the proposed semi-active control law allows for a selective and yet continuous modulation of the damping force, which is essential for the application of drive systems. In the following section, a stability analysis for the 2-DOF drive model with absolute value control will be performed.

sec.title: 2.3. Stability analysis
sec.p: To begin with the variables y1=x1,y2=x1-x2 and their derivatives y3=y·1=x·1,y4=y·2=x·1-x·2 are introduced. The dynamics of the systems and the force term may then be written as follows: (3)(y·1y·2y·3y·4)=(y3y4-km1y2-c1m1y3-csysm1y4(-k(1m1+1m2)y2-c1m1y3 -csys(1m1+1m2)y4+1m2Fd(y))).

Note that the system has always a zero eigenvalue, which describes the state of no motion between the masses. A similar system without the semi-active damping term and simplified constants has been investigated by (Collatz, 1973). There it was shown that the system converges exponentially fast to x1=x2=constant,x·1=x·2=0. A similar behaviour is to expect for the present system.

The system is an ordinary differential equation with Lipschitz continuous right-hand side, due to the control law for Fd. Observe that the last three equations of the system are independent of y1. Therefore, the dynamics of this sub-system can be studied independently: (4)(y·2y·3y·4)=(y4-km1y2-c1m1y3-csysm1y4(-k(1m1+1m2)y2-c1m1y3 -csys(1m1+1m2)y4+1m2Fd(y))) (5)Fd(y) ={c2sgn(y3-y4)(|y3-y4|-|y3|),|y3-y4|-|y3|≥00,otherwise.

Using the Hurwitz’s criteria it can be shown that the real terms of the eigenvalues of the system without the semi-active damping term are always negative provided that all appearing constants are positive. This system has the invariant set I={y∈R3|y2=y3=y4=0}. Physically this set describes the state of no motion between the two masses. As a Lyapunov function, the energy of the system E was chosen as (6)E:=12m1y32+12m2(y3-y4)2+k2y22.

Evidently the sum of potential and kinetic energy is always greater than or equal to zero. Assuming that ‖y‖→∞ and E<∞, then y32, y22 and (y3-y4)2 would have to be bounded. This, however, contradicts ‖y‖=y22+y32+y42→∞. Therefore, E goes to infinity. As a next step the time derivative of E is computed: (7)E'=-c1y32-(y3-y4)Fd(y)-csysy42.

Inserting the damping term finally gives the sought equation: (8)E'={-c1y32-c2|y3-y4|(|y3-y4|-|y3|)-csysy42, |y3-y4|-|y3|≥0-c1y32-csysy42, otherwise.Fd(y) ={c2sgn(y3-y4)(|y3-y4|-|y3|),|y3-y4|-|y3|≥00,otherwise.

With the time derivative of E being always non-positive E'≤0, stability of the sub-system is proven. In order to show asymptotic stability LaSalles’ theorem will be used (Walther, 2000). For the theorem to apply, the damping function Fd(y) has to be locally Lipschitz continuous, so that the derivative of the energy is continuous, and the right-hand side of the ordinary differential equation is locally Lipschitz. This explains the present choice for Fd(y). Finally the biggest invariant subset of stationary points of the Lyapunov function has to be considered: (9)N={y=(y2,y3,y4)t∈R3|E'(y)=0} ={y=(y2,y3,y4)t∈R3|y3=y4=0}.

If a point in this set excluding the origin is chosen y∈N\{0}, then y·3=-(k/m1)y2 and y·4=-(k/m1+k/m2)y2 with initial conditions y3=y4=0 but y2≠0. Thus, the point y does not stay in the set N. Therefore, the biggest invariant subset of N is the origin. This ensures asymptotical stability of the sub-system. Furthermore, it follows that y3 goes to zero. Finally y1 can be obtained by integrating the variable y3: (10)y1(t)=y3(0)+∫0ty3(t)dt.

Figure 7 shows the phase plane trajectories for the sub-system with and without semi-active damping from the same perspective. The two bottom axes express the differences of position and velocity values of the two masses, the height represents the velocity of the first mass. From Figure 7 it can be seen that for both sub-systems the trajectories move to the origin. Furthermore the effect of the semi-active damping is clearly evident. Figure 7.
Phase plane trajectories for the 2-DOF drive model (a) without semi-active damping and (b) with semi-active damping.

In Figure 8 the Lyapunov function is plotted over time with and without semi-active damping. In both cases the Lyapunov function decreases, but the decrease is faster with semi-active damping. Finally, Figure 9 depicts a velocity plot. It can be seen that both systems converge to the origin as expected, but the semi-active damped system oscillates less and moves faster to the origin than the system without semi-active damping. Figure 8.
Decay of the Lyapunov function with and without semi-active damping.
Figure 9.
Velocity plot of the system (a) starting from an initial condition and (b) close-up of the origin with and without semi-active damping.

sec.title: 3. Experimental results
sec.p:
A typical representative for a drive system with high demands on performance, accuracy and reliability are feed drives as used in machine tools. Figure 10 shows a schematic of the set-up of a ball screw feed drive, a classical assembly for this type of application. Figure 10.
Mechanical set-up of the test bench.

Commonly, the actuation of such an electromechanical feed drive is realized by a torque controlled servo motor, which corresponds to the input of the drive model in Figure 2. The transmission elements in this specific case are represented by the ball screw, transforming the rotational motion of the servo drive into linear motion of the machine table. Due to their mechanical composition, these systems are characterized by a dominant and generally slightly dampened eigenmode, which in most cases can directly be ascribed to an axial deformation of the ball screw shaft and its surrounding components (Groß et al., 2006). In the following, the damping characteristic of this axial mode is to be improved by means of semi-active control.

For the experimental validation in the course of this paper, the test bench has been extended by an additional actuator, more exactly a linear direct drive firmly attached to the machine table of the drive system. With this linear direct drive, arbitrary damping forces can be exerted between the machine table and the respective inertial system. By means of an additional condition function in the command controller, this in fact fully active actuator has been limited to behave like an adequate semi-active device, solely capable of dissipating energy. The experimental set-up and the control structure are expressed in Figure 11 and Figure 12. Figure 11.
Control structure of the test bench.
Figure 12.
Feed drive test bench.

The controller for the linear direct drive is realized using a prototyping system, allowing for easy integration of the proposed semi-active control law. During the testing the velocities of servo drive and machine table, incorporating the transmission ratio of the ball screw drive, are detected and fed back to the controller. According to the control law (2), the force command for the linear direct drive is determined. In order to prevent any higher-order modes from being excited (the presented drive system possess yet another dominant mode at 200 Hz) a notch filter has been added to the control path. Owing to the sampling rate of the controller and the high bandwidth of the linear direct drive, dynamical aspects of the damping device itself can be neglected in the following. With the described experimental set-up, various measurements, both in the frequency- and time domain, have been conducted. The optimal value for the damping factor depends on various factors such as the physical parameters of the drive system, dynamical aspects of the actuator or the sampling frequency of the controller. In this case, the value for c2 was determined experimentally. Figure 13 exemplarily shows the frequency response function for the velocities x·1 and x·2 of the servo drive and the machine table, with and without semi-active damping. Figure 13.
Frequency response of the velocity transfer function.

The positive effect of the semi-active damping device is clearly noticeable: both the increase in amplitude and the phase drop at the natural eigenfrequency could be reduced substantially. Accordingly the effect of the semi-active control law is evident in the time domain. Figure 14 shows the response of the machine table for an abrupt change in the position command of the servo drive. Considerably less overshoot and a much faster settling time could be achieved, indicating an improved dynamical behaviour of the drive system. Figure 14.
Measured response of the machine table for a position command step.

Next to the jerk imposed by the input commands, feed drives in machine tools often are subject to external forces arising from the production process (e.g. cutting forces). These forces directly act on the output of the drive system, causing deviations and stability problems. In order to verify the effectiveness of the method proposed, several experiments concerning the disturbance rejection have been conducted. Figure 15 shows the position response of the machine table to external excitation at different frequencies. Figure 15.
Frequency disturbance response of the drive system.

As expected, semi-active damping also leads to an improved disturbance rejection, especially in the region of the system’s natural eigenfrequency. This effect appears quite clearly when looking at the shock response of the system in Figure 16, which was significantly improved in terms of overshoot and tendency towards oscillations. Figure 16.
Measured response of a disturbance step of 1000 N at the machine table.

The individual measurements for both command tracking and disturbance rejection have been conducted at different positions and offset velocities. As arises from the control law, the damping of the additional actuator remains independent of the operating conditions of the drive, guaranteeing a widely linear transmission behaviour for the entire system.

sec.title: 4. Conclusion and summary
sec.p: In this paper we have presented a new technique for improving the damping characteristic of a drive system by means of semi-active damping. A novel semi-active control strategy has been introduced, that better suits the application of high-performance, high-accuracy drive systems. The proposed control law has been explained and stability has been proven for a 2-DOF drive model. Finally the effectiveness of the method has been verified on an experimental test bench. By the use of semi-active damping, the dynamical response of an industrial feed drive could be decisively improved. Oscillations due to excitations on either input or output are systematically suppressed by the proposed control algorithm, allowing for a higher dynamic frequency range and improved positioning behaviour for the investigated drive system. The conducted research proves the applicability of semi-active damping for drive systems and the effectiveness of the method, particularly for slightly dampened systems. Further studies shall provide additional information about the required actuator dynamics and the optimal parameters for the proposed damping strategy. Finally, different semi-active actuators, particularly friction-based actuators, shall be analysed, tested and adapted for their use in drive systems.
